segments.text: They were in the process of trying to change it from a marketing to a total chemical organization when I went in there.
And so we were evolving from marketing into, and that's why I was in the projects and long-range planning was to start the planning process.
Humble Oil still had responsibility for running the manufacturing operation.
In fact, NJ reported to Humble Oil Refining Company in Houston.
Mr. Morgan Davis and then Mr. Ricey.
So the industry, though, really is going through a considerable whatever change, catharsis?
I think Exxon was probably one of the early ones to split off chemicals from petroleum operations to make a separate unit.
We were in the midst of a very high growth era in petrochemicals.
The total size of the chemical business, as I said, in the 63, the year I was there, was $50 billion, all inclusive.
And today it's $1.4, $1.5 trillion.
Well, that's worldwide.
That's all chemical.
Everything.
It was a very small industry in 1963.
So the growth, there was double-digit growth in the petrochemical business from 1960 through the early 70s until the first oil shock.
Tremendous growth in Europe, you know, like 20% a year.
And you're going to stay within J&M for how long?

Well I go from projects and long-range planning to I was given a job as in the plastics division as the operations and planning manager with responsibility to get us into polyethylene and then I became head of the plastics division then I got transferred to Odenton Maryland and
In Maryland, we had a company called NJ Fibers and Laminates.
So it was a fibers and a decorative laminate, one that competed with Formica.
So when you had what you used to make Formica, I knew exactly what you were talking about.
You did that.
We made a product called Nevermar, N-E-V-A-M-A-R. Nevermar?
Yeah.
Is that still a brand?
It's still around, yeah.
And our biggest competitors, there were two of them.
One was Ralph Wilson.
And Ralph Wilson was down in Temple, Texas.
And American Sign of it was made for MICA.
And GE.

GE made decorative laminates until they finally decided to go out of the decorative laminate and they made laminates for these control boards, you know, these electronic... All of those things are nothing more than...
They're exactly... You take one of these...
Boards that go into a computer, that's the same as what was used in Formica, except it doesn't have a decorative sheet on it.
It's phenol formaldehyde.
So then I go down as executive VP of NJ Fibers and Laminates with the responsibility to replace the president.
And he knows I came there to replace him, but nobody else knows.
And so... That's roughly what year now?
Okay.
And I was there 18 months.
And then I moved back to NJ as a vice president with responsibility for half of the product lines.
I'm there for... Yeah, when you say... Yeah, I replaced him.
He left, and I took his place.
We had a strike while I was there, and we had 1,400 employees, so it was a pretty good size operation.
When we had the strike, we were having a few problems with the pickets and things like that, and these two enterprising young girls put an RV across in the parking lot
And the line went over to the RV because they were prostitutes from East Baltimore.
During the strike?
During the strike, and so we had no more prostitutes.
Now that is enterprising.
Yeah, right.
That is enterprising.
The guy who ran the Maryland State Police was a guy named Captain Smith.
I'd always made it a point to meet the chief of police and
in either the state, county, or city, wherever I was.
So if I ever got in trouble, I'd always have somebody to call on.
And so I was good buddies with Captain Smith, and he asked me, you want me to move them?
I said, no, I'll leave them there.
It's better now than it used to be.
Well, now, when you were vice president for the products.
Well, we had 10 product lines, OK?
And I said I had half of them.
the plastics, elastomers, adhesives, fabricated products, and the other guy had the raw materials and industrial chemicals.
That would be ethylene, I mean the olefins, aromatics, the alcohols,
whatever else we had.
M.E.K.
No, you primarily, your day-to-day work is primarily involving production or marketing again?
Everything.
All of the above?
Everything.
That's what I was wondering.
Okay.
Yeah, we're a complete company, but they separated out the chemicals from the oil side officially in 1964.
They formed a separate company, and then in 19...
By 1966, everything was totally separate.
It took about two years worldwide.
So now as the vice president with NJ again, how long was that going to take?
That lasted for six months, and then I got transferred to Europe.
Oh, you really are moving fast.
I moved to Brussels.
I actually moved back.
I got transferred to NJ back in the fall of 69, but I couldn't move until the school semester, which was February.
I moved in February, and on June the 1st, I was on my way to Brussels to look for a place to live.
And when I got my first passport, it was not for

just to take a trip out it was to move so we moved to brussels in the summer of 70. stayed there through the summer of 73. how'd your family like that loved it it was great disappointed to come back what ages were they kids i had one daughter who had three senior rings she had a senior ring in maryland first half the junior year she got a senior ring in

new canaan the second half of the junior year and she got a senior ring in brussels the senior year so she spent one year and graduated from international school of brussels that's a couple of seniors she swore down she wasn't going to go and i told her you know that when you start making the money in the family you make the decisions until then i'll make the decision i said you're going right now she already worked it out to live with somebody i said no way yeah i said no way you're going yeah
And she enjoyed the hell out of it.
So you were in Brussels three years.
My three daughters are four years apart and eight years apart.
So there's a 12-year span.
So we were in Brussels for three years.
I was vice president of SO Chem Group.
And I had responsibility for plastics and elastomers.
Moved back to New York.
and New Canaan.
In 73, as a product line VP, we'd gone to a product line organization where each of the product areas had a VP.
Then I moved in 78 to Houston to run the organization in Houston, which is Exxon Kim Americas.
Okay, now when was that formed, Exxon Kim Americas?
That's NJ.
That is NJ.
NJ changed its name.
When we changed our name to Exxon in 72, we changed Exxon Chemical.
We're the only part of Exxon that uses Exxon worldwide.
The oil side uses Esso outside the U.S. and Exxon in the U.S.
So NJ Chemical Company became Exxon Chem Americas.
In 72?
In 72.
Okay.
It was moved to Houston in 1970, the same time that I moved to Brussels.
We were located on the 610 loop right there where Post Oak is.
We were in one of those twin towers that belonged to Tenneco that's been vacant now because of asbestos.
So you're coming to Houston.
In 78, so first time back.
I stayed here for three years.
Now why was that decision made?
Why move that?
Well, it was the next step up, you know, from the standpoint.
We had both a product line organization and a renewal organization.
And the regional organization did
basically the implementation, which run the manufacturing plants and do the selling.
The product lines basically did the planning, the strategic planning of where we're going.
So it was a different type of experience.
So I came down here in 78 and was here for three years.
Built this building while we were here.
We were, as I said, on 610 Luke.
And your title, again, here now?
President of Exxon Kim Americas.
President of Exxon Kim Americas.
Right.
And that's where I was when Holland first formed his group on the Lindsay thing.
Yeah, his first advisory group.
Well, I went there in 1966.
I recommend that I go there.
So I was here three years and then I get transferred back to New York as the executive vice president of Exxon International.
So after spending what 26 years in the chemical business
I get transferred to the oil side.
And I spent four and a half years as vice president of Exxon International.
Okay, let's see those dates.
Let me get roughly those.
Okay.
Now, my guess is you were really traveling the world about that time, were you?
I did more traveling when I was the VP of Plastics in New York.
Is that right?
Yeah.
That's when I went to Saudi Arabia 27 times.
I negotiated the agreement with the Saudis for building a plant in Jebel.
And since we were working in New York City, you don't count the days you're out of the country or out of the state.
for tax purposes, and you keep accurate records.
I was outside the U.S. in 19, what was it, 76, 63% of the days.
What was the thrust now of Exxon International in those years, 81, 85?
Exxon International basically is the supply arm to all of Exxon's petroleum operations.
They run the marine operation, which is the transportation of crude oil.
They acquire the crude oil.
They do all of what we call contract-type sales.
In other words, they sell aviation gasoline.
They sell ship bunkers.
They sell ship lubes.
So it's a...
Supply, transportation, and commodity type trading.
And you're primarily involved in movement, distribution, planning.
Yep.
We had the third largest Navy in the world.
126 ships.
In tonnage, it was the third largest.
We were smaller than the U.S. and the Russian Navy.
So, and in 85, now, and you're based, you're stationed now, you're based out of New York.
Well, we were in New York until 83, and we moved to New Jersey, okay?
The company moved to New Jersey.
So I was in New Jersey at that time, and I knew that Ed Homer was going to retire as president of Exxon Chemical in 86, and lo and behold, in 85,
They transferred me to Reliance Electric to take the job as president of Reliance Electric to get me out of the way, I thought.
And I went out there as executive VP working for a guy named John Morley, and they were going to move Morley to New York.
He was a treasurer by background.
They couldn't find a job for him in New York, so they put off my taking over his job
from January 1st to April 1st.
Then they put it off from April 1st to July 1st.
And then they put it off from July 1st to September 1st.
And by that point in time, we'd already made plans to sell Reliance Electric.
So I'm there 15 months from October of 85 to December the 31st, 86.
And I never take over the job I went out there to take.
I had the option of staying with the Reliance, and I said, no, I'm going to go back.
So they offered me a job, which was vacant at that time, as executive vice president of Exxon Chemical.
And it was located in Derry Inn.
So that was January 1, 87.
And in 1990, in December, the
the guy who just retired as president of Exxon named Chuck Sitter, he came to me and he said, how much longer are you willing to work?
And I said, about another six months.
Why?
I said, I'm tired of the Northeast.
I want to go back to Texas.
He said, well, what did it take to get you to stay for five years?
At that time, I'm 57.
I said, we'd had to move the company to Texas.
He said, well, go ahead.
And that's the way it was?
That's the way it was.
I said, well, I'll come down and make a presentation.
You really had not thought about that.
They said, don't bother.
And then they called me up and said, don't bother to come down.
There's one place you can't go to.
I said, where is that?
They said, that's Dallas.
I said, well, hell, that's no problem.
I said, I was going to take it to Marshall anyway.
There are two places you can't go to.
That actually happened.
Two places you can't go to.
So we moved down here in the summer of 91.
So from December, we didn't waste much time.
We moved as soon as the school year was out.
And none of this was on track or online before this happened?
No.
This came up in December and
February, I came down looking for office space.
And in June, July, we were occupying offices over in Westlake, you know, Amoco building next door.
And while we built this section on the added section on this building here.
So the guy who was running the company at that time,
that they already knew he was retiring and that's why they asked me if I'm willing to stay for five years and so he retired at the end of 91 and I've been running the chemical company since then.
So you've been here since 91 in this location?
In this location since 91.
And when we got here so late in the year, I couldn't get tickets to the damn football game.
And I said, what would it take to get, you know, some preferred seating type tickets?
They said, well, you've got to give an endowed scholarship.
I said, okay.
So I gave an endowed scholarship, got my two tickets.
That's the hard way to do it.
It was costly.
If you could have come to the history department, I think we could have done something.
Yeah.
Now, what direction?
Where are chemicals going?
Where is Exxon Chemicals going?
Petrochemicals?
Well, you know, our basic objective is to become a bigger part of Exxon.
We've normally been 10% of their sales and about 10% of their capital.
In sales, since the price of crude oil was up last year, we're still 10% of their sales.
We're about...
14 or 15% of their capital and about 16 or 17% of their earnings.
And we want to be 20% of the capital in earnings five years from now.
And what does it take to do that?
It takes a lot of investments.
Yeah, more plant?
Yeah.
International?
Domestic?
Basically, we're going to spend most of our capital in Asia Pacific.
Most of our big capital in Asia Pacific.
We're currently...
Working on two projects, I guess.
One's $2 billion and the, well, three, if you talk about China.
It'll be in the league of $2 billion.
And then we've got over a billion dollars we're spending in Saudi Arabia right now.
All to supply Asia Pacific.
In what?
In polyesters?
In gasoline?
Ethylene, propylene, polyethylene, polypropylene.

Oxo alcohols, phthalic anhydride, plasticizers that go into PVC, solvents, but you know, we don't have to expand things like butyl rubber or Vistalon or some of the other types of products because they're things that can be shipped worldwide.
So we've come from number 15 in the world when we separated out in the early 60s, 62, 63, with sales of $375 million to where this year we'll do, last year we did $13.5 billion.
We have roughly 14,000 employees plus about 4,000 contractors.
but that's down from 18,000 employees and 6,000 contractors in 1990.
So we've been coming down while our volume's been going up.
That's just kind of across the board in American industry.
That's right.
American industry is probably in the best shape from the standpoint of competitiveness they've been in a long time.
Well, I think I better stop you right there.
That sounds like we've covered that.
a great part of the ballpark.
I'm going to work on this and get it into that manuscript here, there, hither and yonder, and I'll flag those areas and, if you don't mind, send it back to you.
All right.
And I really appreciate your review.
